column1: '''[[Illuin]]''' ("sky-blue" in [[Quenya]]) and '''[[Ormal]]''' ("high-gold") were great lamps which once stood respectively at the northern and southern ends of [[Arda]] in primeval times

column2: there was a misty light veiling the barren ground. The Valar took this light and concentrated it into two large lamps.{{fact}}

column1: [[Aulë]] forged great towers on which to place the Lamps
column4: and another in the deepest south
column5: [[Ringil (tower)|Ringil]]. [[Varda]] filled them with light and [[Manwë]] hallowed them.<ref name=s1/>

column2: where the light of the Lamps mingled and the vegetation of [[Yavanna]] was richer
column3: was the [[Great Lake]] and the island [[Almaren]]
column4: where the Valar first dwelt.<ref name=s1>{{s|1}}</ref>

column1: The lamps were destroyed by an assault by [[Morgoth|Melkor]]. Their fall was cataclysmic: The symmetry of Arda was destroyed as the weight of the lamps broke continents and their fire burned the land
column2: such that the original design of the Valar
column4: was undone forever. The Valar did what they could to hinder the damage as Melkor their Enemy and his hosts fled back to [[Utumno]]. As they didn't know when or where the [[Children of Eru]] would come into the world
column5: they were afraid to rend the Earth again.<ref name=s1/>

column1: At the site where Illuin fell
column2: the inland sea of [[Sea of Helcar|Helcar]] was formed
column3: of which [[Cuiviénen]] was a bay. There was also the [[Sea of Ringil]] to the south
column4: perhaps associated with the roots of Ormal.

column2: and after repairing some of the damage done by the resulting tumult
column3: the Valar left Middle-earth for [[Valinor]]. There the Valar created the [[Two Trees of Valinor|Two Trees]]
column4: which were also a pair of gold and silver light
column5: as the Two Lamps before them.

column1: [[Christopher Tolkien]] noted that the story of the Lamps in its early stage was very different from the published ''[[Silmarillion]]''.
According to older writings not used in the published [[The Silmarillion]]
column2: the Valar wanted peace with Melkor
column3: and decided to ask his assistance: they wished to fix the lamps upon Arda's ground. Melkor
column4: black with hate and envy of the rest of the Valar
column5: agreed to help. He gave Aulë a substance which was both sturdy and strong: ice
column6: which was unknown to the Valar. Melkor bided his time and allowed the Valar to do as they wished until the fateful day when the Lamps' light and heat melted the ice and crashed upon Arda
column7: flooding it with water and darkness.

column1: The one remaining influence from the older version of the story was that the fall of the towers created inland seas
column2: a vestige of the notion that the towers had been made of ice that melted.<ref>{{LT1|IIIn}}

column1: In Tolkien's latest writings where Arda was a [[Round World version of the Silmarillion|round world]] from its beginning
column2: the Two Lamps never truly existed and were instead a subject of Númenórean mythology.<ref>{{MR|Myths}}</ref>
